text: Section 1 of 5 minutes stories. This is a Librevox recording. All Librevox recordings are in the public domain.
For more information or to volunteer, please visit Librevox.org, recording by Ruhi Hak.
5 minutes stories by Nora Irijets, Section 1, Betty. When I sit and hold her little hand, my Betty,
then all the little troubles seem to shrink, grow small and petty. It does not matter anymore
that ink is filled on parlour floor, that gown is caught upon the latch and not the smallest bit to match.
The cook is going, house may gone and coming guests to meet alone. It matters, not at all you see,
for I have Betty and Betty has me. When I sit and hold her little hand, my Betty, then all the simple foolish baby talk grows wise and witty.
I am glad to know that Prusimau was frightened at the wooden cow. I read for Dali's broken head,
and for the sawdust she has shed. I take with joy the cups of tea from wooden tea pot poured for me,
and all goes well because you see, I play with Betty and Betty with me.
When I walk and hold her little hand, my Betty, then every humble bead beside the way grows proud and pretty.
The clover never was so red, the pureest white the daisy spread. The butter cups begin to dance,
the reeds salute with lifted lads, the very tallest trees we pass,
bend down to greet my little lads, and these things make my joy you see, for I love Betty and Betty loves me,
